item.title: Inside Ukraine's Quest to Keep the Lights On as Winter Descends
item.description: Ukraine is scrambling to repair electricity production crippled by a Russian bombing campaign, seeking parts abroad and at a front-line power plant.

item.title: Making Fun of Men in China Comes at a Cost
item.description: Chinese companies are trying to exploit burgeoning interest in women-focused content without upsetting male customers.

item.title: Haiti's Ruling Council Fires Acting Prime Minister
item.description: The poorest country in the Americas has been rocked by political turmoil since the assassination of President Jovenel Moïse.

item.title: China Struggles to Shake Off Deflationary Pressures
item.description: China’s consumer prices edged up in October, while factory-gate prices continued to decline, underscoring the challenges Beijing faces in battling deflationary pressures despite a recent stimulus push.

item.title: The Russia-Ukraine War Intensifies, With Drone Attacks, Foreign Troops and Record Losses
item.description: The surge in fighting occurs as President-elect Donald Trump pledges to end the conflict.

item.title: Calls for 'Jew Hunt' Preceded Attacks in Amsterdam
item.description: Police in the Dutch capital are investigating how the assaults last week in Amsterdam against Israeli soccer fans were coordinated.

item.title: Why North Korean Soldiers Are Prepared to Die in Russia
item.description: Nearly all would raise their hands to go, ex-military defectors explain, owing to regime loyalty, promise of higher status and a glimpse of the outside world.

item.title: China Courts U.S. Allies as Defense Against Trump's Protectionism
item.description: Fearing a U.S. tariff barrage, Beijing hopes to use “proactive” tariff cuts and investment offers to peel away American partners in Europe and Asia.

item.title: Qatar Pauses Efforts to Mediate Stalled Gaza Cease-Fire
item.description: The Gulf state’s move reflects frustration with the lack of progress by Hamas and Israel.

item.title: Russia Explores Plan to Merge Oil Giants Into Mega Producer
item.description: The resulting company would be the world’s second-largest crude producer, behind Saudi Arabia’s Aramco, and would pump almost three times the output of Exxon Mobil.

item.title: A Xi Enforcer Is Revving Up China's Spy Machine---and Alarming the West
item.description: The intelligence agency accused of steering cyberattacks on the U.S. has grown more powerful with a trusted protégé of the Chinese leader at the helm.

item.title: A Damaged and Degraded Hezbollah Wages Guerrilla Campaign Against Israel
item.description: The group’s fighters stay hidden for days, or even weeks, before launching hit-and-run attacks on Israeli troops.

item.title: Antisemitic Attacks in Amsterdam Prompt Tight Security at Jewish Sites
item.description: Dutch Prime Minister Dick Schoof condemned an overnight wave of violence as Israel begins efforts to evacuate its citizens.

item.title: Ukrainian Soldiers Say Trump's Peace Push Could Come With a Huge Cost
item.description: A rapid conclusion to the war now would likely leave Kyiv with the rough end of the deal.

item.title: Families Battle Tech Giants as Australia Pushes for an Under-16 Social-Media Ban
item.description: The proposal marks the latest effort by political leaders worldwide to regulate children’s use of platforms, amid concerns that it is harming their mental health.

item.title: Europe Urges Trump to Support Ukraine but Braces for Possible Cut in U.S. Aid
item.description: European leaders have discussed how to help Ukraine fend off Russia without Washington’s support, even as they try to convince the president-elect not to cut aid to Kyiv.

item.title: China Moves to Ease Debt Concerns---but Again Holds Off on Stimulus Measures
item.description: Investors’ hopes for large-scale support for the economy were dashed after an anticipatory stock-market surge in recent weeks.

item.title: U.N. Agency Aiding Millions of Palestinians Is in Jeopardy---and There's No Plan B
item.description: On a typical day in Gaza, Unrwa provides food to around 2,000 families and healthcare to thousands more. Israel last week passed laws aimed at halting those operations.

item.title: Tycoon Drives India's Push Against China's Solar-Energy Dominance
item.description: Gautam Adani, the founder of one of India’s biggest business conglomerates, lies at the intersection of the country’s clean energy challenge to China.

item.title: German Political Crisis Leaves Europe Rudderless Ahead of Trump's Return
item.description: With both France and Germany led by minority governments, the continent’s key powers are likely to be consumed by domestic politics as challenges pile up.
